instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.C1802: What is C1802? Capacitor to ground on PCH_SRTCRST_L on machines from 2009-2012, PCH_SRTCRST_L needs to be high for PCH to not be in RTC reset mode, this capacitor can become corroded or leaky and result in this signal being pulled low. .
definitions.C1803: What is C1803? Capacitor to ground on RTC_RESET_L on machines from 2009-2012, RTC_RESET_L needs to be high for system to not be in RTC reset mode, this capacitor can become corroded or leaky and result in this signal being pulled low. .
definitions.5V_S3: What is 5V_S3? 5V_S3 is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S3” which is a 5 volt power rail present in an S3 state. S3 (Suspend to RAM) is a state where the system saves its context to RAM, a faster but more power-consuming method than S4. The system shuts down most components except for RAM, which remains powered to retain the system state. PM_SLP_S4_L is required for this rail to be present. .
definitions.SMC_RESET: What is SMC_RESET? SMC_RESET is not a signal, it is an abbreviation for “SMC_RESET_L”, which is the signal someone is referring to when they type “SMC_RESET”  "SMC_RESET_L is a signal that resets the SMC when it is low(this is what the “_L” prefix means), and lets the SMC out of reset mode when it is high. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesn’t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PCH_INTVRMEN_L: What is PCH_INTVRMEN_L? PCH_INTVRMEN_L is a signal that stands for Internal Voltage Regulator Enable. When pulled high, this signal enables the internal 1.05 V regulators for the Suspend well in the PCH. This signal must be pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H..
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Board had mild water damage. All components were replaced that had corrosion, smc was reflowed and board went in uc afterwards. It worked for a few minutes and then died.

Currently I have a green light and all power rails up to <SIGNAL>PP5V3_S3</SIGNAL> is missing. I already checked and replaced <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>. pin 16 is 16v. what should I check next?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Exact PPBUS voltage? Voltage on <CAPACITOR>C1802</CAPACITOR>/03?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: 12.60v PPBUS   3.325V <CAPACITOR>C1802</CAPACITOR>   3.325v <CAPACITOR>C1803</CAPACITOR>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Crap under SMC still likely. Make sure it is not power cycling at all on <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL>!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Can’t be crap under the smc, already replaced smc

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: 16V on pin 16 from <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>? PPBUS 12.6V? So, what is it then, both voltages should be the same....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: 12.6V on pin 16 <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>  ppbus 12.60v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: You saw the original water damage. The fact that it worked and then died usually point to a corroded resistor or corrosion under a chip. It all depends on where the corrosion was.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: While it was working i attempted a smc reset and thats when it died. Do I need to replace smc again?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET</SIGNAL> will not hurt anything like that. It is corrosion under some chip or a corroded resistor/trace. Again, it all depends on where the corrosion was.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Can someone assist me with this board with more suggestions?  recap I have all power rails up to <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>. Dont have a short to ground pin 16 of <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> is 12.60v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Do you get any pulse at L7260, or other secondary supplies?
Apart of L7220, which must have stable 3V3...

Post <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_AN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>.
Check 32KHz clock to SMC.
Try to start shorting power pads (<RESISTOR>R5015</RESISTOR>/16) and check if <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> reacts.
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> should rise first.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
0.007V on l7260. doesnt move from there

<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> 0V

0.427 32KHZ CLOCK pin 12  <CHIP>U2600</CHIP>

shorted pads and <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> didnt react

<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>  didnt react

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>"???

Check PPVRTC and all 4 (four) RTC signals.
SMC crystal Y5010 oscillates?
32KHz present at SMC input?
<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> is high?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> 0V

<SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 3.482V

<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> 0.412v

<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> 3.199v

<SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN_L</SIGNAL> 3.338V

Do not own a oscilloscope to check Y5010 oscillating

How do you check for 32KHz?

<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> 3.487V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> should be higher around 3.3V
Check if <RESISTOR>R1802</RESISTOR> measure ok, hard for a 20 kohms to go high but still possible it happens. Check also if any corrosion underneath the resistor ( I mean corrosion on the pad). Check also <CAPACITOR>C1802</CAPACITOR>.
See if any short on pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R1802</RESISTOR>.

It could be a pch issue also... I had an smc with <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> low stuck at 1.4v, but no short at all, when I heated smc <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> went 3.3v and back to 1.4v when cold...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> 0.412v"
PCH is kept in reset, no need to measure oscillation anymore.
<CAPACITOR>C1802</CAPACITOR> is the first suspect here.
If not, bad PCH (hope not the case)...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Ok I have cleaned the pads up and replaced <CAPACITOR>C1802</CAPACITOR> and <RESISTOR>R1802</RESISTOR> but still same results. First time I have run into a board with this issue, however I have the ability to replace the pch. Does anything need to be done to the bios after pch is replaced?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Of course, new PCH requires clean ME region...

Did you check resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>PCH_SRTC_RST_L</SIGNAL>?
Check it again with removed PCH and compare values.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
PCH has been replaced.

<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> is now 3.481V but still no fan spin. Is this because I need clean ME region?

resistance to ground without PCH 0.741 and with replacement PCH 0.406

Here is backup of bios [url]https://drive.google.com/file/d/1xofkyYTHY-SzEwEGH1fF8qgOj-Xd8oMC/view?usp=sharing[/url]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Secondary voltages should appear even without SPI chip soldered; less the CPU ones.
So, <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> should pulse at least; check that.

Post again all the signals mentioned in the previous posts...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> does not pulse at all

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> 0V

<SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 3.482V

<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> 3.481V

<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> 3.195V

<SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN_L</SIGNAL> 0V

<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> 3.487V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Noticed there was a short on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>.

Soldered SPI chip back on for testing. Replaced <CHIP>U7801</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> and now <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is pulsing at 3.3V with a quarter fan spin every few seconds.

Do I just need new ME region now? If so can someone provide?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> 0V"
PCH doesn't want to set it high.

And here is the reason.
"<SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN_L</SIGNAL> 0V"
This signal should be high now, if machine tries to start.

"<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is pulsing at 3.3V"
Check if all voltages controlled by it pulse too.
Do the same for <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>.
Also look if <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> pulses.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
suddenly lost my old voltages since I last checked this board. I have nothing for <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> now and no more quarter fan spin.

pp3v42 3.42 V but no green light <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> only 1.060V now

what to check next in this case?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7085</TRANSISTOR> now back to quarter fan spin

all voltages for <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> are pulsing along with <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Do you note pulsing CPU coils too?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: cpu coils pulsing at 0.971V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: 25MHz oscillation tries to appear at pin9/<CHIP>U2600</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: I have the fluke 15b+ multimeter and I do not believe it supports MHz oscillation. Is there another way to check?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Try this as is; if works, then you may change the serial...
[url]https://drive.google.com/open?id=1RFRVA7vkn2gGPN7hpuXlNwLCIiMrNx5G[/url]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Just tried it but nothing has changed. Anything else I can try?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Check if all the voltages from page 72 try to appear.
Also check all SPI termination resistors and traces around <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>.
